awd_titl_txt: Nuclear Physics Studies at Fermilab and PSI
awd_abstract_narration:
The main physics program supported by this grant is directed at the study of those properties of nucleons and nuclei that are influenced by the size of the proton.  As the proton is a nucleon, and one of the principal components of nuclei, knowing its size precisely is critical to understanding fundamental nuclear structure.  Yet measurement of the proton's size through two independent means has yielded different results.   The source of this difference has been a 10-year old puzzle that this project hopes to solve. Research will be carried out at two places: one at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (Fermilab) near Chicago as part of a collaboration called SeaQuest, and the other at the Paul Scherrer Institute near Zurich, Switzerland, as part of a collaboration called MUSE. Education and training of both undergraduate and graduate students, as well as outreach aimed at the general public, is an important aspect of this research program. 

The experiment at Fermilab is focused on Drell-Yan production of dimuon pairs to determine the light anti-quark distributions in the nucleon.  It will provide a better understanding how light anti-quarks are distributed in unpolarized and polarized nucleons, and how orbital angular momentum might contribute to the nucleon spin. This information will provide direct input to theoretical models of the proton, and shed light on the origin of the proton's spin. The MUSE experiment will simultaneously measure elastic scattering with electrons and muons off protons which is afforded by a beam that contains positively and negatively charged electrons, muons and pions.  The experiment aims to resolve the unexplained large discrepancy of the size of the proton measured with electron and muon scattering.  This discrepancy was entirely unexpected, as the proton's size should not depend on whether it is measured with electrons or muons. This approach has never been attempted before.  In addition, the Michigan group will lead the operation of a liquid hydrogen target at the MUSE experiment, and lead the analysis effort at the SeaQuest experiment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit:

The main physics program supported by this grant was directed at the study of the flavor and spin structure of nucleons and nuclei, and at reassessing the proton charge radius and the discrepancies that remain.

Research was carried out at two places: one at the Fermilab Laboratory near Chicago as part of a collaboration called SeaQuest and its successor, called SpinQuest, as well as at the Paul Scherrer Institute near Zurich, Switzerland, as part of a collaboration called MUSE. The experiment at Fermilab was focused on Drell-Yan production of dimuon pairs to determine the light anti-quark flavor and spin distributions in the nucleon. The result of the SeaQuest experiment, published in the prestigious Nature journal, provided direct input to theoretical models of the proton's subatomic antimatter structure, and the results of the upcoming SpinQuest experiment are expected to shed light on the origin of the proton's spin. The experiment in Switzerland aimed to resolve discrepancies in the size of the proton measured with electron and muon scattering, where the muon is a heavy cousin of the electron. The discrepancies were unexpected, as the proton's size should not depend on whether it is measured with electrons or muons. The Michigan group has built the liquid hydrogen target for the MUSE experiment, and plans to lead the analysis effort at the SeaQuest experiment.  Once the experiment is completed we expect to report ground-breaking new results.

Broader Impacts:

The project has provided the students who worked on the project the skills to do careful analyses of large data sets as they are common for research performed at accelerator based nuclear and particle physics experiments. They have learned how to program in Python, ROOT and LabView, they have experience with the Linux operating system, and some have experience in grid computing, which is available to undergraduate and graduate students at U-M. Many students have gained experience in cryogenic target design and LH2 target cell construction and testing, and some have learned about FPGA programming and trigger logic. In addition, all group members were trained to improve their skills to communicate scientific results to the research community at national and international conferences and workshops.

The project has also provided our postdocs with opportunities for career development. During weekly meetings, progress and occasional challenges, as well as strategies for mitigation were discussed. This helped them sharpen their leadership skills. All three postdocs were put in charge of important experimental components of the experiments at Fermilab and PSI. Two of the postdocs had the opportunity to substantially contribute to all aspects of a recently submitted NSF proposal to prepare for the time when they likely have to submit her own proposals, while the third postdoc was involved in writing an annual progress report. This has provided them first-hand experience in these important aspects of leading their own research groups in the future.

In a testament to their work, two of our postdocs and one graduate student were recognized for their contributions to the SpinQuest experiment. One postdoc was a recipient of the 2020 Fermilab Intensity Frontier Fellow Award, while the other was the recipient of the 2021 URA Visiting Scholars Award, and the graduate student was a recipient of the 2020 URA Visiting Scholars Award.
